terms.definition: The region of wire adjacent to the ball bond that experiences thermal softening during the EFO process. Controlled by dopants like Beryllium or Calcium in gold wire.
High-voltage spark process that melts the wire tip inside a ceramic capillary to form a Free Air Ball (FAB). For copper wire, requires forming gas environment.
The spherical ball formed at the wire tip by the EFO process before bonding. Ball diameter is typically 2x-3x the wire diameter.
Condition where the wire fails to properly weld to the bond pad, typically due to contamination or oxidation. Modern bonders can detect this via impedance monitoring.
Brittle gold-aluminum intermetallic compound that forms at elevated temperatures (>300°C), appearing purple in color. Can lead to bond failure over time.
Another brittle gold-aluminum intermetallic compound that forms at elevated temperatures. Along with Purple Plague, contributes to Kirkendall void formation.
Gas mixture (typically 95% N₂ / 5% H₂) used to create an oxygen-free environment during copper wire bonding EFO process to prevent oxidation.
Ceramic tool through which wire is fed during ball bonding process. The outer radius of the capillary tip forms the stitch bond shape.
The second bond in a wire loop, formed by crushing the wire against the substrate using the outer radius of the capillary. Often the weakest link in the bond.
The transition point where the wire changes from the flat bonded area to the round wire loop. Susceptible to cracking from excessive ultrasonic power or tool wear.
Lateral movement of wire loops during plastic molding encapsulation, potentially causing shorts between adjacent wires. Prevented by using worked loops.
Percentage of bond area that has formed a proper intermetallic weld between wire and pad. Typically requires >60-80% coverage for qualification.
The height to which the capillary rises before performing reverse motion during looping. Controls the loop profile shape.
At high frequencies (>10 GHz), current flows only on the surface (skin) of the conductor. Round wires have higher impedance due to skin effect; ribbon wire reduces this.
Cracking of the silicon or dielectric under the bond pad, causing the pad to lift off with silicon attached. Particularly problematic with hard copper wire.
The ratio of bonded ball diameter to wire diameter. Typically should be 2x-3x the wire diameter for proper bonding.
Visual defect where the ball is not centered on the wire stem, resembling a golf club. Indicates capillary tip misalignment - reject condition.
Reliability test using high humidity (85%), high temperature (130°C), and electrical bias to check for corrosion. Critical for copper and silver wires.
Reliability test that accelerates intermetallic growth in gold wire bonds. Used to evaluate Purple Plague and Kirkendall void formation.

Machine vision system that automatically inspects wire bonds for defects including ball size, position, loop height, wire sweep, and missing bonds. Typical resolution ≤2 µm/pixel for fine pitch applications.
Statistical measure of process capability relative to specification limits. Cpk = min[(USL - μ)/(3σ), (μ - LSL)/(3σ)]. Values ≥1.33 indicate capable process; ≥1.67 required for automotive.
Systematic methodology to determine relationships between process factors (force, power, time, temperature) and outputs (bond strength, quality). Used to optimize wire bonding parameters efficiently.
Method of quality control using statistical methods to monitor and control wire bonding processes. Includes control charts for pull strength, shear strength, and ball diameter.
Global standards organization for the microelectronics industry. Develops test methods for wire bonding including JESD22-B116 (shear test) and JESD22-B125 (pull test) specifically for copper wire.
Trade association that develops standards for electronics manufacturing including IPC-TM-650 test methods for wire bond pull and shear testing on PCB substrates.
Ratio of bonded ball diameter to original wire diameter. Acceptable range is 2.0x-3.5x wire diameter, with optimal at 2.5x-3.0x. Indicates proper bonding force application.
Wire pull test failure where wire breaks just above the ball at the heat-affected zone. This is the IDEAL failure mode indicating the bond is stronger than the wire itself.
Wire pull test failure where wire breaks at the heel of the stitch bond (transition from flat to round). May indicate worn tools or excessive ultrasonic power.
Failure mode where the ball or stitch bond separates from the pad surface. Indicates process failure such as contamination, insufficient bonding energy, or oxidation. Always a reject condition.
Height at which the shear tool chisel is positioned above the pad during ball shear testing. Must be 10-15% of ball height. Too high gives false pass; too low damages pad.
Location where the pull test hook engages the wire loop. Must be at the loop apex (highest point) for valid test results. Mid-span placement changes trigonometric forces and invalidates data.
Stress test qualification standard for integrated circuits used in automotive applications. Defines temperature grades (0-3) and reliability test requirements.
U.S. military standard defining test methods for microelectronics. Method 2011 covers wire pull testing; Method 2023 covers ball shear testing. The industry 'Bible' for wire bond testing.
